section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to engage children, and introduce vocabulary (warm, alone).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What could you do when you have a cold?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Identify and solve problems.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Use information to categorize; Use information to compare and contrast.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to classify different things that are good and bad for a cold.
Guide children to talk about how to care for themselves when they have a cold.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Show me a character who is doing something to stay healthy.
Pretend you have a cold and you are blowing your nose.
What can you do when you are sick so that other people don’t get sick, too?
Can you draw a picture of something you should do when you have a cold?
Make something you might use to stay healthy. What materials will you use?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word healthy? Can you make that sound?
Can you use blocks to build a good place for someone to rest when they have a cold?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder problem solving and to introduce vocabulary (solve, around).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to What A Cold Needs.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builders.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words; Understand multiple-meaning words.
Identify and solve problems.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Exercise good habits of personal safety.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to look at different objects and act out how to use them when you have a cold.
Guide children to talk about why these objects are helpful or not helpful.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find some pictures of people doing things to stay healthy?
Act like you have a cold and are shopping for things to help you feel better. What will you get?
Can you think of two things that a cold needs?
Can you draw a picture that shows how you feel when you are doing something healthy?
Can you draw or paint a plate showing healthy foods?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word cold?
Can you build something that helps you feel better when you have a cold?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. What a Cold Needs by Barbara Bottner, illustrated by Chris Sheban. Text copyright © 2018 by Barbara Bottner. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Chris Sheban. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Holiday House Publishing, Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Make a Connection, and introduce vocabulary (near, gentle).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question, What can you do to feel better when you have a cold?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use a growing number of relational words.
Identify and solve problems.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Use information to categorize; Use information to compare and contrast.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children explore different ways germs can spread when you have a cold.
Guide children as they act out the role of the germs and how they spread.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do the characters in the book take care of themselves?
Can you show me the face you might make when you are feeling sick.
How many healthy foods can you think of that start with the letter M?
Can you make up a story about a sick child who tries different things to feel better?
Can you make a picture that shows the story that you created?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word near?
Can you build a place where you might go when you are feeling sick? What place would you build?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. What a Cold Needs by Barbara Bottner, illustrated by Chris Sheban. Text copyright © 2018 by Barbara Bottner. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Chris Sheban. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Holiday House Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Keep Your Hands Clean

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about taking care of themselves and to introduce vocabulary (scrub, rinse).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Keep Your Hands Clean and What a Cold Needs.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, How can we stay healthy?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Follow oral directions.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Focus attention (Self-Regulation).
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to follow step-by-step directions to wash their hands.
Guide children to talk about why washing hands is important.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find characters that are doing something healthy?
Pretend to wash your hands.
What steps do you need to follow to keep your hands clean? What is step 1? What is step 2?
Can you write about why it is important to wash your hands?
Can you draw the first and last steps of washing your hands?
Which letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the words nap and nose?
Can you use blocks to create a place where you can wash your hands?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. What a Cold Needs by Barbara Bottner, illustrated by Chris Sheban. Text copyright © 2018 by Barbara Bottner. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Chris Sheban. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Holiday House Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out being sick, and to introduce vocabulary (silly, quiet).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, When you have a cold, what can you do to get your mind off it?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words; Understand and use a growing number of relational words.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Identify and solve problems.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Use art for self- expression.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt, What would you tell a sick friend to do to feel better?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote a book about staying healthy, what would you put in it?
Pretend you are a doctor caring for a sick person.
Can you name two things that happen to you when you get a cold?
Create a story about a superhero who makes sick people feel better. What would your superhero look like?
Can you draw a machine that could help people wash their hands?
Imagine a face made of letters. What letters would you use for the eyes? The nose? The mouth?
Create something you can play with that would help you feel better. What materials would you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. What a Cold Needs by Barbara Bottner, illustrated by Chris Sheban. Text copyright © 2018 by Barbara Bottner. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Chris Sheban. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Holiday House Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Name at least 20 upper- and at least 20 lowercase letters in the language of instruction.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Practice good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Demonstrate coordination and balance in isolation.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Practice good habits of personal safety.
Demonstrate coordination and balance in isolation.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Intentionally use marks, letters or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Practice good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways.
Remain focused on engaging group activities.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Practice good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
